catalog.title: Manufacturing Processes
catalog.description: Examines manufacturing processes including casting, forming, cutting, joining, and molding of various engineering materials (metals and non-metals). Also studies manufacturing considerations in design including material and process selection, tooling, product quality, and properties/processing tradeoffs. Includes quality control and automation issues.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 381.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 381
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.

catalog.title: Digital Control Systems
catalog.description: Characterization of discrete time systems; analysis of discrete control systems by time-domain and transform techniques; stability analysis (Jury test, bilinear transformation, Routh stability test); deadbeat controller design; root-locus based controller design; discrete state variable techniques; synthesis of discrete time controllers; engineering consideration of computer controlled systems.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 340 and MAE 376; MAE or ENS Majors only.
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 340 and MAE 376; MAE or ENS Majors only

catalog.title: Mech Propts of Materials
catalog.description: Relationship between the microstructure of materials and their macroscopic properties; topics include strength and modulus, hardness, fatigue, creep and plasticity, abrasion, impact, elasticity, thermal stresses, strengthening mechanism, and testing methods.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 381; Approved ASE and ME Majors only.
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 381; Approved ASE and ME Majors only

catalog.title: Cardiovascular Biomechans
catalog.description: Introduces the mechanical behavior of the cardiovascular system, basic physiology, and application of engineering fundamentals to obtain quantitative descriptions. Major topics include rheology of blood, mechanics of the heart, dynamics of blood flow in the heart and circulation, control of cardiac output, blood pressure, and regional blood flow.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 335 or (BE 308 and EAS 207); refer to MAE Progression Criteria in your academic advising report for additional requirements; Approved ASE and ME majors only.
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 335 or (BE 308 and EAS 207); refer to MAE Progression Criteria in your academic advising report for additional requirements; Approved ASE and ME majors only

catalog.title: Nano/Microtechnologies MEMS
catalog.description: Introduces advanced technologies that enable integration of micro-sensors and micromechanical components on the same chip to produce miniature devices called micro electromechanical systems (MEMS). The course covers physical principles and design rules that govern the performance of a device at small length scales. Discuss a large set of microfabrication techniques including photolithography, material removal processes, and additive technologies. Discuss the applications of MEMS devices in automotive, communication, energy, and BioMEMS in biomedical applications.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 381; ASE and ME Majors only.
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 381; ASE and ME Majors only

catalog.title: Design Project
catalog.description: Students working in teams of two or three under the supervision of a faculty member complete an original engineering design, which in some cases results in hardware. Design problems are drawn from industry and initiated by faculty. Where practical, two or more teams compete to solve the same problem. Teams meet individually with faculty on a weekly basis to discuss their projects.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Co-Requisite: MAE 451.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.
catalog.corequisites:
MAE 451
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.

catalog.title: Robotics II
catalog.description: The objective of this course is to provide working knowledge required to formulate and analyze problems related to the application of collaborative robots. This course will also provide methodologies for solutions to such formulated problems. This course is the same as IE 483, and course repeat rules will apply.  Students should consult with their major department regarding any restrictions on their degree requirements.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: Permission of instructor OR MAE 493 Robotics I.
catalog.prerequisites: Permission of instructor OR MAE 493 Robotics I

catalog.title: Engineering Internship
catalog.description: Provides experience in real-world engineering problems for senior mechanical and aerospace students. Assigns projects from local industry. Normally requires students to spend eight hours weekly in an engineering office. Students must present written and oral reports. Students interested in an internship or co-op experience should also consider the EAS 396 and EAS 496 sequence.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.requisites: Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only

catalog.title: Cad Applications
catalog.description: Considers concepts in computer-aided engineering including principles of computer graphics, finite element analysis, kinematic analysis, and animation of mechanical systems. Studies the use of integrated CAD/CAE tools. Incorporates projects in solid modeling, stress analysis of machine parts and structures, and mechanism response and animation.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 376; Approved ASE and ME Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 376; Approved ASE and ME Majors Only

catalog.title: Cad Applications
catalog.description: Considers concepts in computer-aided engineering including principles of computer graphics, finite element analysis, kinematic analysis, and animation of mechanical systems. Studies the use of integrated CAD/CAE tools. Incorporates projects in solid modeling, stress analysis of machine parts and structures, and mechanism response and animation.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: MAE 376; Approved ASE and ME Majors Only.

catalog.title: Cad Applications
catalog.description: Considers concepts in computer-aided engineering including principles of computer graphics, finite element analysis, kinematic analysis, and animation of mechanical systems. catalog.prerequisites: MAE 376; Approved ASE and ME Majors Only

catalog.title: Materials Experimental Methods
catalog.description: This lecture course will cover experimental methods in materials science and engineering. These methods will relate to the characterization of material structures (using spectroscopy, microscopy and diffraction techniques), material properties (mechanical, thermal, electrical, electrochemical, etc.) and material processes (phase transformations, reactions, diffusion, etc.).  Illustrations will be made using materials including metals, ceramics, polymers, carbons, semiconductors and composites. This course is dual-listed with MAE 589.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.long_title: Experimental Methods in Materials Science and Engineering
catalog.requisites_description: MAE 489 Pre-Requisite: MAE 381 and Mech/Aero Majors.
catalog.requisites: MAE 489
catalog.prerequisites: MAE 381 and Mech/Aero Majors

notes.note: Complete a Forced Registration Application on the SEAS Portal.

catalog.title: Research/Creative Act
catalog.description: Students collaborate with faculty research mentors on an ongoing project in a faculty member's laboratory or conduct independent research under the guidance of a faculty member.  This experience provides students with an inquiry based learning opportunity and engages them as active learners in a research setting. Arrangements must be made with a specific faculty member before registration.

catalog.description: Students collaborate with faculty research mentors on an ongoing project in a faculty member's laboratory or conduct independent research under the guidance of a faculty member.  This experience provides students with an inquiry based learning opportunity and engages them as active learners in a research setting. Arrangements must be made with a specific faculty member before registration.

catalog.title: Machines & Mechanisms 1
catalog.description: Examines analysis and design of machine elements, including theories of failure, fatigue strength, and endurance limits; fluctuating stresses; Goodman diagram; and fatigue design under torsional and combined stresses. Also covers design of bolted connections, fasteners, welds, springs, ball and roller bearings, journal bearings, gears, clutches, and brakes.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: EAS 209.
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.
catalog.prerequisites:
EAS 209
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.

catalog.title: Machines & Mechanisms 1
catalog.description: Examines analysis and design of machine elements, including theories of failure, fatigue strength, and endurance limits; fluctuating stresses; Goodman diagram; and fatigue design under torsional and combined stresses. Also covers design of bolted connections, fasteners, welds, springs, ball and roller bearings, journal bearings, gears, clutches, and brakes.

catalog.title: Machines & Mechanisms 1
catalog.description: Examines analysis and design of machine elements, including theories of failure, fatigue strength, and endurance limits; fluctuating stresses; Goodman diagram; and fatigue design under torsional and combined stresses. Also covers design of bolted connections, fasteners, welds, springs, ball and roller bearings, journal bearings, gears, clutches, and brakes.

catalog.prerequisites:
EAS 209
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.

catalog.title: Intermediate Dynamics
catalog.description: Intermediate dynamics is a preliminary course in modeling dynamical systems for mechanical and aerospace engineering students. Fundamentals methods of kinematics and kinetics for a system of particles are presented with applications to physical systems. This discussion is followed by the development of equations of motion of a rigid body, including the study of torque free motion and conservation principles. Constrained motion is discussed briefly along with a short study of impulsive motion.  The concept of equilibrium points for dynamical systems is introduced and methods of linear analysis are discussed in conjunction with linearization about the equilibrium point. The course concludes with an exposition of vibration theory and its relationship to Eigenvalue problems.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite:  EAS 208.
Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
EAS 208
Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.

catalog.title: Aerospace Structures
catalog.description: Explores the theory of light structures including beam bending, shear stress, shear center, and composite beams; shear flow, warping stresses, and secondary warping; torsion of thin-walled single and multi-cell tubes; deformation  of struts, plates, frames, and trusses; stress analysis of connections; composite structures and sandwich construction. Also covers computer implementation with applications to aircraft and aerospace structures.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 315.
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 315
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.

catalog.title: Aerospace Structures
catalog.description: Explores the theory of light structures including beam bending, shear stress, shear center, and composite beams; shear flow, warping stresses, and secondary warping; torsion of thin-walled single and multi-cell tubes; deformation  of struts, plates, frames, and trusses; stress analysis of connections; composite structures and sandwich construction. Also covers computer implementation with applications to aircraft and aerospace structures.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 315.
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 315
Mechanical or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.

catalog.title: Heat Transfer
catalog.description: Introduces the transport of heat by conduction, convection, and radiation. Topics include transient and steady-state, one- and multidimensional heat conduction (treated both analytically and numerically); single-phase, laminar and turbulent, and forced and natural convection both within ducts and on external surfaces (dimensional analysis and empirical correlations); two-phase transport (boiling and condensation); radiative properties of materials and analysis of radiative heat transfer in enclosures; and analysis of heat exchangers.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 204.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 204
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering or Engineering Science Majors Only.

catalog.title: MAE Laboratory I
catalog.description: Introduces digital data acquisition systems.  A/D convertors, and amplifiers. Error analysis. Transducers for mechanical and electrical measurements.  Static and dynamic response of electrical and mechanical elements and systems.  Modifying dynamic response using feedback control.  One lecture and one three-hour laboratory weekly.

notes.note: CO-REGISTER LECTURE

catalog.title: Introduction to CAD
catalog.description: The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with a 3D modeling CAD software platform, like Creo Parametric. Students will learn basic 3D modelling functions such as extrude, revolve, pattern, sweep, etc. The course will cover integration of individual parts into assemblies. Documenting CAD models through the use of engineering drawings will also be covered.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Approved and Intended Engineering or ENS Majors Only
catalog.requisites: Approved and Intended Engineering or ENS Majors Only

notes.note: CO-REGISTER LAB

catalog.title: Introduction to CAD
catalog.description: The purpose of this course is to familiarize students with a 3D modeling CAD software platform, like Creo Parametric. Students will learn basic 3D modelling functions such as extrude, revolve, pattern, sweep, etc. The course will cover integration of individual parts into assemblies. catalog.requisites: Approved and Intended Engineering or ENS Majors Only

catalog.title: Aircraft Design
catalog.description: Involves practice predicting performance of existing designs with comparison to actual performance; and analyzes performance of new, student-designed aircraft. Conceptual aircraft design for specific mission profiles is facilitated by course-licensed software.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 436.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 436
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.

catalog.title: Space Dyn & Ctrl
catalog.description: Introduces the concepts of spacecraft orbital mechanics and attitude dynamics.  Orbital mechanics is the study of the positional motion, while attitude dynamics describes the orientation of the spacecraft.  Topics include:  review of rotational kinematics and dynamics, orbital mechanics, gravity turn and trajectory optimization, orbit lifetimes, three-body problem, orbit perturbations, orbit determination, spacecraft dynamics, spinning and three-axis stabilized spacecraft, and attitude determination.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 345 and 376.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 345 and 376
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.

notes.note: Not recommended for ME-only students

catalog.title: Aerodynamics
catalog.description: Explores flow over airfoils and wings; ideal flow theory; singularity solutions; superposition; source; and vortex panel methods; method of source panels; 2-D airfoil theory; pressure distributions and lift; effects of compressibility; Prandtl's lifting-line theory; boundary-layer theory; and friction drag. Includes an aerodynamics laboratory experience, considering airfoil characteristics, and boundary-layer measurements.

catalog.requisites_description:

Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.
catalog.prerequisites:

catalog.title: Aerodynamics
catalog.description: Explores flow over airfoils and wings; ideal flow theory; singularity solutions; superposition; source; and vortex panel methods; method of source panels; 2-D airfoil theory; pressure distributions and lift; effects of compressibility; Prandtl's lifting-line theory; boundary-layer theory; and friction drag. Includes an aerodynamics laboratory experience, considering airfoil characteristics, and boundary-layer measurements.

catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 335.
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.

catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 335
Mechanical Or Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
Students must satisfy the SEAS faculty advisement requirement.

notes.note: Students will apply knowledge of fluid mechanics, heat transfer, and thermodynamics towards the design of fluid-thermal systems. Given design goals and a concept design, students will break complex systems down into sub-systems, develop fluid-thermal models for the sub-systems, then apply optimization schemes to produce an optimized design. It is strongly recommended that students have taken or are taking Fluid Mechanics, Thermodynamics, and Heat Transfer alongside this course.

catalog.title: Special Topics
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Approved Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.requisites: Approved Engineering Majors Only

catalog.title: Intro to Propulsion
catalog.description: Reviews combustion thermodynamics; flow in nozzle, diffuser, and constant area duct with shock; analysis and performance of air breathing and chemical rocket propulsion systems; performance of single and multi-staged rocket vehicles; and space missions.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description:
Pre-Requisite: MAE 335 and MAE 422.
Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.prerequisites:
MAE 335 and MAE 422
Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Majors Only.

catalog.title: Special Topics
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Approved Engineering Majors Only.
catalog.requisites: Approved Engineering Majors Only

catalog.title: Musculoskeleta Biomech
catalog.description: Reviews basic aspects of anatomy including forces transmitted in the body, bones as structural members, and joint and muscle forces. Also considers kinematics of body motions, instantaneous centers of joint motions, behavior of normal and abnormal joints, remodeling, biomaterials, and ligaments and tendons. Also studies functions of orthotics and prostheses, including design considerations. Involves a weekly seminar and one or two laboratory sessions.
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-Requisite: EAS 209.
catalog.prerequisites: EAS 209

notes.note: The mechanical and other physical properties of materials can be dramatically different when the characteristic dimensions of the system are confined to small length-scales below 100 nm. These size-scale effects in mechanics result from the enhanced role of surfaces and interfaces, defects and material variations, and quantum effects. Understanding of the fundamental nanomechanics and the manipulating of those phenomena are key to the application of advanced manufacturing (AM), micro-electro-mechanical (MEMS) or nano-electro-mechanical (NEMS) fabrication, lubricant industries, surface and interface engineering, soft/miniaturized robotics, biomechanical materials/devices etc. This course will have a focus on fundamentals and applications of atomic/molecular interactions, phonon, contact mechanics, nano-tribology, and scanning probe microscopy (SPM) system.

The unique topics and expert guest line-up for this course promise to provide a great insight into the latest trends in this fast evolving and exciting field. There will also be exceptional opportunities to hear from NASA's Nature Inspired Program, Grand Challenges, or many other cutting edge on-Earth or Space developmental activities in the field, such as bioinspired robotics and planetary, surface or ocean explorations, human missions and settlement plans, and DNA research and anti-aging in conjunction with future astronaut programs, etc.

catalog.title: Special Topics
catalog.subject: Mechanical & Aerospace Engr
catalog.requisites_description: Pre-requisite: Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Majors Only
catalog.prerequisites: Approved Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering Majors Only

catalog.title: Engng Materials Lab
catalog.description: Involves experiments designed to illustrate the relationships among the processing, internal structure and properties of engineering materials, emphasizing metals and their heat treatment, microstructure and mechanical properties.  Provides hands-on experience in metallography, heat treatment and mechanical testing. Includes laboratory report writing and work in groups.
